volved. BGXA asked Italians: In your opinion, which of the following three
countries showed the most hostility to Italy after the war — France, sagland
and Russia.
In the overall survey, only two per cent of the Italians polled siad
France had been moat hostile. Forty one per oent said Britain and 37 per cent
said Russia. eleven per cent of those responding said all three of these
countries had been hostile to Italy and only two per cent said none of the
three had shown hostility* Perhaps three historical reminders should be in¬
serted at this pointi
1* Many Italians have long nursed a deep resentment against Britain as
the nation which consistently thwarjsed Italy's ambitions — colonial and other¬
wise — in the Mediterranean area*
2. The British army contributed to the World War II debacle of the Ita¬
lians in Africa* then fought on Italian soil for nearly two years* and finally
stayed on as an occupying power once the war was over* The Soviet army, on
the other hand, has never been on Italian territory.
3. And finally, the British have been responsible for the administration
of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste and were blamed for the violence
and deaths of last autumn.
These factors may help account for the overall result of the DOiXA pell,
in which 41 per cent of the Italians said England had shown the most hostility
to Italy in this postwar period against 37 per cent who listed Russia* In
DOSCa’b breakdown according to educational background, the result was somewhat
different. Persons with the most formal education among those polled said that
Russia had shown the most hostility to Italy, although the margin was not great
between the Soviet Union and England.
DUX.A also broke down answers to this question according to geographic
location. The polling agency found that in the sou$h of Italy and in the is¬
lands, Including Sicily and Sardinia, the Italian people thought Russia had
shown greater hostility than England in the postwar years. But in the north¬
ern and central parts of Italy, about 46 per cent said Ihgland had demonstrated
the greatest hostility, compared with 37 per cent who named Russia as the major
offender.
Once again, the political party breakdown was what one could anticipate.
Among Communists and left Socialists, 70 per cent said Itagland had shown the
most hostility, against eight per cent who listed Russia. But among Christian
Democrats, only 23 per cent called England the greatest offender, against 54
per cent who named the Soviet Union.
DGDUk’a last question was worded this way* “Whet acts of Russia, hostile
to Italy, -have hurt it th^most?*
Thirty three per cent of Italians polled listed the Soviet Union’s de¬
tention of Italian crooners captured during World War II. It has been esti¬
mated that upwards of 60,000 Italians were so detained* only a relative handful
have come back. And the Italians clearly resent this more than anything else
the Soviet Union has done. In second place, cited by 19 per cent of those
polled, is Russia’s persistent veto of Italy’s admission to the United Nations.
Six per cent cited Moscow*s hostility to the return of Trieste to Italy* nine
per cent cited Russia’s claim for war Indemnities* and five per cant listed
